snippet: The plan could demonstrate that governments are willing to cede power to the strong institutions that many economists say are needed to stabilize the currency union.
abstract: European officials propose linking banking systems more closely under growing international and financial market pressure to fix the region's problems; plan could demonstrate that governments are willing to cede power to the strong institutions that economists say are needed to stabilize the euro and union.

byline.original: By JACK EWING and JAMES KANTER
byline.contributor: Jack Ewing reported from Frankfurt and James Kanter from Brussels. Reporting was contributed by David Jolly from Paris, Nicholas Kulish from Berlin, Annie Lowery from Washington and Hiroko Tabuchi from Tokyo.

lead_paragraph: The plan could demonstrate that governments are willing to cede power to the strong institutions that many economists say are needed to stabilize the currency union.

headline.seo: A Tighter Bond Proposed for Europe’s Banks
headline.main: Tighter Banking Ties Are Proposed in Europe
headline.print_headline: Amid Calls for Action, A Tighter Banking Bond Is Proposed in Europe
